step 2:

data.title: vscode 1.17 crashes docker and Mac OS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

I'm afraid it's a bit complicated. I'll try to explain the best I can and hopefully someone else ran into a similar issue.

The crash (Mac OSX crash: all applications are killed, except vscode!) occurred when clicking on "continue debugging" after vscode stops on a breakpoint. The nodejs process runs inside a docker container. 

The crash does not occurs in vscode 1.16.  

System logs:
Oct  6 11:32:16 titane kernel[0]: process com.docker.drive[4978] caught causing excessive wakeups. Observed wakeups rate (per sec): 7225; Maximum permitted wakeups rate (per sec): 150; Observation period: 300 seconds; Task lifetime number of wakeups: 45002
Oct  6 11:32:16 titane com.apple.xpc.launchd[1] (com.apple.ReportCrash[4985]): Endpoint has been activated through legacy launch(3) APIs. Please switch to XPC or bootstrap_check_in(): com.apple.ReportCrash
Oct  6 11:32:16 titane ReportCrash[4985]: Invoking spindump for pid=4978 wakeups_rate=7225 duration=7 because of excessive wakeups

data.title: Tasks are not detected
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.17.0 (be377c0faf7574a59f84940f593a6849f12e4de7, 2017-10-04T23:33:45.303Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-59-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.18
indenticator|Sir|0.4.2
prettier-vscode|esb|0.24.0
hungry-delete|jas|1.3.3
graphql-for-vscode|kum|1.6.2
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
mono-debug|ms-|0.15.7
embrace|myc|1.0.0
yo|sam|0.9.3
visualclojure|sti|0.0.2
ayu|tea|0.8.0

(4 theme extensions excluded)


---

My package.json contains scripts:

```
  "scripts": {
    "start": "gulp watch",
    "build": "gulp build",
    "debug": "node --inspect-brk dist/index.js",
    "serve": "forever -a -v -m 20 --minUptime 20000 --spinSleepTime 20000 --no-colors  dist/index.js"
  },
```

According to [this](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks), these should be auto-detected. However, I see "no tasks found" when I enter `task` in the command window.

I also have `gulpfile.js` in the project, with tasks `build` and `lint` defined. According to the same URL, I was expecting these to be auto-detected as well - they are not.

So I create my own task. After quite a bit of fixing the standard templates (they have `taskName`, for instance), I ended up with this:

```
{
      "group": {
        "kind": "build",
        "isDefault": true
      },
      "label": "build",
      "type": "npm",
      "script": "build"
    }
```

However, this task is still not being detected. If I *Run Build Task* from the menu, the message says "No build task to run found".

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Double character when typing accents on macOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Long press a button like E
2. Press 2 to select "é" for instance
3. The editor writes `eé` instead of just `é`

This is a problem to type string content in languages using accents and other character alterations.

What happens is pretty clear, the first character is immediately written on "keyDown", when it should probably wait for something like "keyUp".

data.title: Support import intellisense in <script> tags in .html files
data.body: The new autocomplete suggestions for `import` in 1.17 are great — would it be possible to support them inside `<script>` tags in .html files?

data.title: Customise extensions that import intellisense recognises
data.body:
As of VSCode 1.17, typing `import x from './` offers autocomplete suggestions of local files and directories. However, the list of file extensions that are recognised is somewhat arbitrary — .js files are recognised, as are .ts and .jsx, but .json isn't (despite the fact that the Node handles .json files natively).

Meanwhile, when building web applications with bundlers like Webpack and Rollup, it's common to import files with extensions like .css, .html, .vue, .tsv and so on.

Is there some way to customise the list of extensions that are recognised? An alternative approach could be to recognise all file extensions rather than attempting to filter them.

data.title: Add file extensions when auto-completing import paths
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.17.0 (be377c0faf7574a59f84940f593a6849f12e4de7, 2017-10-05T06:07:51.906Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Handlebars|and|0.2.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.2
prettier-vscode|esb|0.24.0
vscode-import-cost|wix|2.5.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open or create a JavaScript file
2. Start typing `import x from './` followed by the name of a sibling file

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

When you start writing a local `import` statement, the intellisense helper will offer up `foo` and `bar` rather than `foo.js` and `bar.js`. Extensionless imports is a Node idiom that is **incompatible with browser module loaders** — adding the file extension would increase browser compatibility with no ill-effect on Node apps (to the contrary, it speeds up [module resolution](https://nodejs.org/api/modules.html#modules_all_together), and I'd argue it makes code more explicit and readable).

I wonder if you would consider changing the behaviour to add file extensions by default?

data.title: Unable to use ctrl-p in the integrated terminal in GNU/Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.17.0 (be377c0faf7574a59f84940f593a6849f12e4de7, 2017-10-04T23:33:45.303Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-96-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
rust|rus|0.3.1
vim|vsc|0.10.1
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch and give focus to the integrated terminal
2. Hit ctrl-p

---

Expected behavior:

Previously executed command should be in the buffer ready to execute.

Note: This works as expected on macOS (presumably because cmd-p is used there for Go To File)

---

Actual behavior:

Go To File in command prompt opens

---

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

Would it be sane to not trigger Go To File if the terminal has focus?

I realize this is an edge-case and special casing things like this isn't desirable.

I don't want to suggest yet-another-setting because that becomes a nightmare to maintain and troubleshoot.

data.title: [BUG] Activity Bar refresh bug over loading extension marketplace list
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0 c[ be377c0faf7574a59f84940f593a6849f12e4de7 ]
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 64-bit & Linux Ubuntu 16.04.2 Gnome 3

Steps to Reproduce:

---

[Lang = "CZ/SK"]
Ak budete veľmi rýchlo skrývať a zobrazovať ikony v activity bar, tak bežne sa v panelu zobrazuje práve ten ktorý bol naposledy odkrytý alebo ten ktorý je nad skrytým, to je ok, ale ak takýmto spôsobom otvoríte extension marketplace list, a zároveň počas načitávania extensions bude naďaľej rýchlo skrývať a zobrazovať ikony v Activiry Bar, tak občas sa stane že sa naďalej graficky bude ukazovať ikona v activity bar, niekedy funguje na ňu kliknúť, niekedy nie, ovšem v zoznamu "show/hide" nieje pri danej ikone/položke fajka. Alebo naopak je, ale ikona / položka sa nezobrazuje, niekedy ovšem keď kliknete na prázdne miesto v activity bar, otvoríte aj skrytú položku. Problém je s reprodukovaním, pretože sa to udeje náhodne a len občas / zriedkavo. Ak sa to stane, tak celý panel a aktivity bar je zabugovaný až kým nevypnete a znova nezapnete vscode.

---

[EN - translated by google translator]

If you hide and display icons in the activity bar very quickly, so the one that was last exposed or the one that is hidden is usually in the panel, but if you open the extension marketplace list, you will also be able to open the extension extensions to quickly hide and display icons in the Activiry Bar, sometimes it happens that the icon in the activity bar will continue to be shown graphically, sometimes it's clickable on it, sometimes not, but in the "show / hide" list it is not the icon / brier item. Or vice versa, but the icon / item is not displayed, but sometimes when you click on a blank space in the activity bar, you also open the hidden item. The problem is with reproduction because it happens at random and only occasionally / rarely. If this happens, the entire panel and activity bar is bugged, you must close and again open vscode to fix it.

---

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

![screenshot_84](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31345346/31278489-67d78822-aaa5-11e7-8b4e-169357ce8117.png)

---
[lang = "CZ/SK"]
P.s. Ak niekto vie prekladať z češtiny alebo slovenčiny do angličtiny, prosím o pomoc, totiž neco málo po anglicky viem, a neprijde mi že preklad je správny. (aj keď si to dám preložiť spätne, tak to preloží chujovinu).

[EN - translated by google translator]
P.s. If someone can translate from Czech or Slovak into English, please help, I know little about English and I do not think the translation is correct. (even though I'm going to translate it back, so it translates the stupid

data.title: Updates notified before they are available
data.body: On Centos 7 visual studio code always notifies about an update before it is actually available to install. The Centos repositories at https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode/ seem to take a day or so to be updated but the UI bugs you about an update being available as soon as the update is released. It'd be nice to delay the notification until the update is actually installable
